title: Frankie's YELLOW PAGES ... Volume I
historical_context: This article is part of the Cow's Information Series (C.I.S.) and reflects the early days of phone phreaking, a subculture that exploited the telephone system.
short_summary: This article serves as a comprehensive encyclopedia of Bell System terms and acronyms, providing valuable insights for phreakers and telecommunications enthusiasts.
summary:
In 'Frankie's YELLOW PAGES ... Volume I', F. Gibe presents an extensive glossary of terms and acronyms used within the Bell System, aimed at phreakers and those interested in telecommunications. The article is both informative and humorous, reflecting the playful yet serious nature of the hacking culture of the time. It covers a wide range of topics, from basic definitions like 'Address' and 'Analog Signal' to more complex concepts such as 'Automatic Number Identification' and 'Adaptive Transversal Equalizer'. Each entry is crafted with a blend of technical accuracy and wit, making it accessible to both novices and seasoned phreakers alike.

The glossary not only serves as a reference for understanding the telecommunications landscape but also highlights the intricate workings of the phone system that phreakers sought to exploit. By demystifying the jargon, Gibe empowers readers to navigate the world of telecommunications with confidence. This article is a testament to the creativity and resourcefulness of the phreaking community, encapsulating a unique moment in the history of hacking culture where knowledge was both a tool and a form of rebellion against corporate control.
